Core_Mechanics.The_d20: The d20 is the core die. Roll it for attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws. Higher rolls are better.
Core_Mechanics.Ability_Scores: Six abilities: Strength (STR), Dexterity (DEX), Constitution (CON), Intelligence (INT), Wisdom (WIS), Charisma (CHA). Scores range from 1 to 30.
Core_Mechanics.Modifiers: Ability score modifier = (Score - 10) / 2, rounded down. E.g., a score of 14 has a +2 modifier.
Core_Mechanics.Proficiency_Bonus: A bonus added to rolls with which a character is proficient (attacks, skills, saves). Increases with level: +2 (Levels 1-4), +3 (Levels 5-8), +4 (Levels 9-12), +5 (Levels 13-16), +6 (Levels 17-20).
Core_Mechanics.Advantage_Disadvantage: Roll two d20s. Advantage: use higher roll. Disadvantage: use lower roll. They cancel each other out; multiple instances don't stack.
Core_Mechanics.Rounding: Round down for fractions unless specified otherwise.

Combat.Surprise: If surprised, you can't move or take an action on your first turn of combat, and you can't take a reaction until that turn ends.
Combat.Initiative: At the start of combat, each participant rolls initiative (1d20 + DEX modifier) to determine turn order, highest to lowest.
Combat.Your_Turn: On your turn, you can move up to your speed and take one action. You can also take one bonus action (if available) and one reaction (if triggered).

Actions_In_Combat.Attack: Make one melee or ranged attack. Some features allow multiple attacks.
Actions_In_Combat.Cast_a_Spell: Cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action.
Actions_In_Combat.Dash: Gain extra movement equal to your speed.
Actions_In_Combat.Disengage: Your movement doesn't provoke opportunity attacks for the rest of the turn.
Actions_In_Combat.Dodge: Until the start of your next turn, any attack roll made against you has disadvantage if you can see the attacker, and you make Dexterity saving throws with advantage.
Actions_In_Combat.Help: Grant an ally advantage on an ability check or on an attack roll against a creature within 5 feet of you.
Actions_In_Combat.Hide: Make a Dexterity (Stealth) check to become hidden.
Actions_In_Combat.Ready: Choose a trigger and an action. If the trigger occurs before your next turn, you can use your reaction to take the action.
Actions_In_Combat.Search: Devote your attention to finding something. Make a Wisdom (Perception) or Intelligence (Investigation) check.
Actions_In_Combat.Use_an_Object: Interact with a second object or feature of the environment.

Combat.Bonus_Actions: Various class features, spells, and other abilities allow you to take an additional action on your turn called a bonus action. You can take only one bonus action on your turn.
Combat.Reactions: A reaction is an instant response to a trigger of some kind, which can occur on your turn or on someone else's. You get one reaction per round.
Combat.Movement: You can move up to your speed. You can break up your movement during your turn, using some of your speed before and some after your action.
Combat.Difficult_Terrain: Moving through difficult terrain costs 2 feet of speed for every 1 foot moved.
Combat.Being_Prone: You can drop prone without using any speed. Standing up costs an amount of movement equal to half your speed. While prone, you have disadvantage on attack rolls. An attack roll against you has advantage if the attacker is within 5 feet, otherwise it has disadvantage.
Combat.Opportunity_Attacks: If a hostile creature you can see moves out of your reach, you can use your reaction to make one melee attack against it.
Combat.Two_Weapon_Fighting: When you take the Attack action and attack with a light melee weapon, you can use a bonus action to attack with a different light melee weapon in your other hand. You don't add your ability modifier to the damage of the bonus attack, unless that modifier is negative.
Combat.Grappling: Using the Attack action, you can make a special melee attack, a grapple. If you're able to make multiple attacks with the Attack action, this attack replaces one of them. The target of your grapple must be no more than one size larger than you. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. If you succeed, the target is grappled. A grappled creature's speed becomes 0.
Combat.Shoving: Using the Attack action, you can make a special melee attack to shove a creature, either to knock it prone or push it 5 feet away from you. Make a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the target's Strength (Athletics) or Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. If you succeed, you either knock the target prone or push it 5 feet away from you.

Making_an_Attack.Attack_Rolls: Roll 1d20 + ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient). If the total equals or exceeds the target's Armor Class (AC), the attack hits.
Making_an_Attack.Unseen_Attackers_and_Targets: When you attack a target you can't see, you have disadvantage. If you are hidden, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that can't see you.
Making_an_Attack.Ranged_Attacks: Ranged attacks have a normal range and a long range. Attacking at long range imposes disadvantage. You can't make a ranged attack if a hostile creature is within 5 feet of you.
Making_an_Attack.Melee_Attacks: Most creatures have a 5-foot reach for melee attacks.
Making_an_Attack.Critical_Hits: A natural 20 on an attack roll is a critical hit. Roll all of the attack's damage dice twice and add them together. Then add any relevant modifiers as normal.
Making_an_Attack.Critical_Miss: A natural 1 on an attack roll always misses, regardless of modifiers or AC.

Damage_and_Healing.Damage_Rolls: Roll the appropriate damage dice and add modifiers. Typically, weapon attacks add the ability modifier used for the attack roll.
Damage_and_Healing.Damage_Types: Common types include Acid, Bludgeoning, Cold, Fire, Force, Lightning, Necrotic, Piercing, Poison, Psychic, Radiant, Slashing, Thunder.
Damage_and_Healing.Resistance_Vulnerability: Resistance: take half damage. Vulnerability: take double damage. Multiple instances don't stack.
Damage_and_Healing.Healing: Restores hit points. Cannot exceed maximum HP. Some spells and abilities heal.
Damage_and_Healing.Dropping_to_0_Hit_Points: When you drop to 0 HP, you either die outright or fall unconscious.
Damage_and_Healing.Instant_Death: Massive damage can kill you instantly. If damage reduces you to 0 HP and there is damage remaining, you die if the remaining damage equals or exceeds your hit point maximum.
Damage_and_Healing.Falling_Unconscious: If damage reduces you to 0 HP but fails to kill you, you fall unconscious. This unconsciousness ends if you regain any hit points.
Damage_and_Healing.Death_Saving_Throws: While at 0 HP and unconscious, at the start of each of your turns, make a death saving throw (d20, no modifiers). 10 or higher: success. 9 or lower: failure. Three successes: you become stable. Three failures: you die. Rolling a 1 counts as two failures. Rolling a 20 means you regain 1 HP.
Damage_and_Healing.Stabilizing_a_Creature: Use an action to make a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check on an unconscious creature at 0 HP. Success means the creature is stable.
Damage_and_Healing.Temporary_Hit_Points: Temporary HP aren't actual HP; they are a buffer. They are lost before actual HP. They don't stack; you take the highest amount if you gain more. They can't be healed.

Spellcasting.What_is_a_Spell: A spell is a discrete magical effect, a single shaping of the magical energies that suffuse the multiverse into a specific, limited expression.
Spellcasting.Spell_Level: Every spell has a level from 0 to 9. A spell's level is a general indicator of how powerful it is.
Spellcasting.Cantrips: Level 0 spells. Can be cast at will without using a spell slot.
Spellcasting.Spell_Slots: Casting a spell of 1st level or higher requires expending a slot of that spell's level or higher. Regained after a long rest.
Spellcasting.Casting_Time: Most spells require 1 action. Some are bonus actions, reactions, or take longer.
Spellcasting.Range: The maximum distance from you that the spell can affect.
Spellcasting.Components: Verbal (V): spoken incantation. Somatic (S): gestures. Material (M): specific items. A spellcaster must have a hand free to access material components or to perform somatic components.
Spellcasting.Duration: How long the spell lasts. Instantaneous, 1 round, 1 minute, 10 minutes, 1 hour, etc. Concentration spells require focus.
Spellcasting.Concentration: Some spells require concentration. You can concentrate on only one spell at a time. If you take damage while concentrating, make a Constitution saving throw (DC 10 or half the damage taken, whichever is higher). On a fail, you lose concentration. Casting another concentration spell also breaks concentration.
Spellcasting.Targets: Spells specify targets: creatures, objects, or a point of origin for an area of effect.
Spellcasting.Areas_of_Effect: Cone, Cube, Cylinder, Line, Sphere. Spells specify how to determine the area.
Spellcasting.Saving_Throws: Many spells allow targets to make a saving throw to avoid some or all of the spell's effects. Spell Save DC = 8 + proficiency bonus + spellcasting ability modifier.
Spellcasting.Attack_Rolls_for_Spells: Some spells require an attack roll. Spell Attack Modifier = proficiency bonus + spellcasting ability modifier.

Ability_Checks.Description: Roll 1d20 + ability modifier + proficiency bonus (if proficient in the skill). Compare to a Difficulty Class (DC) set by the GM.
Ability_Checks.Difficulty_Class_Examples: Very Easy (DC 5), Easy (DC 10), Medium (DC 15), Hard (DC 20), Very Hard (DC 25), Nearly Impossible (DC 30).
Ability_Checks.Contests: When two creatures compete, both make ability checks. The one with the higher result wins. Ties mean the situation remains the same.
Ability_Checks.Passive_Checks: A passive check is 10 + all modifiers normally applied to the check. Used when a character isn't actively trying, or for the GM to secretly determine if characters notice something.
Ability_Checks.Working_Together: Multiple characters can help each other. If one character leads, others can help, granting advantage to the leader's check if the help is effective.
Ability_Checks.Group_Checks: When a group attempts something, if at least half the group succeeds on their individual checks, the whole group succeeds.

Resting.Short_Rest: A period of downtime, at least 1 hour long, during which a character does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending to wounds. Characters can spend Hit Dice to regain HP. Some class features recharge.
Resting.Long_Rest: A period of extended downtime, at least 8 hours long. A character must have at least 1 hit point at the start of the rest to gain its benefits. Regain all lost HP. Regain spent Hit Dice, up to a number of dice equal to half of the character's total number of them (minimum of one die). Most spellcasters regain all spent spell slots. Some class features recharge. Can't benefit from more than one long rest in a 24-hour period.
Resting.Hit_Dice: Characters have a pool of Hit Dice they can spend during a short rest to regain HP. The number of Hit Dice equals the character's level. The type of die is determined by class.

Conditions_Detailed.Blinded: Can't see, fails ability checks requiring sight. Attack rolls against have advantage, creature's attacks have disadvantage.
Conditions_Detailed.Charmed: Can't attack or target charmer with harmful abilities/magic. Charmer has advantage on social ability checks with creature.
Conditions_Detailed.Deafened: Can't hear, fails ability checks requiring hearing.
Conditions_Detailed.Exhaustion: Levels 1-6. 1: Disadvantage on ability checks. 2: Speed halved. 3: Disadvantage on attacks/saves. 4: HP max halved. 5: Speed reduced to 0. 6: Death. One level removed per long rest.
Conditions_Detailed.Frightened: Disadvantage on ability checks/attacks while source of fear is in line of sight. Can't willingly move closer to source of fear.
Conditions_Detailed.Grappled: Speed becomes 0. Ends if grappler is incapacitated or if an effect removes grappled creature from reach of grappler.
Conditions_Detailed.Invisible: Impossible to see without aid of magic/special sense. Considered heavily obscured for Hiding. Attack rolls against have disadvantage, creature's attacks have advantage.
Conditions_Detailed.Paralyzed: Incapacitated, can't move/speak. Fails STR/DEX saves. Attacks against have advantage. Any attack that hits from within 5 feet is a critical hit.
Conditions_Detailed.Petrified: Transformed to stone. Weight increases x10, ceases aging. Incapacitated, can't move/speak, unaware. Fails STR/DEX saves. Attacks against have advantage. Resistance to all damage. Immune to poison/disease.
Conditions_Detailed.Poisoned: Disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.
Conditions_Detailed.Prone: Only movement is crawl (half speed). Disadvantage on attacks. Attacks against have advantage if attacker is within 5ft, else disadvantage.
Conditions_Detailed.Restrained: Speed 0. Attacks have disadvantage. DEX saves have disadvantage. Attacks against have advantage.
Conditions_Detailed.Stunned: Incapacitated, can't move, can speak only falteringly. Fails STR/DEX saves. Attacks against have advantage.
Conditions_Detailed.Unconscious: Incapacitated, can't move/speak, unaware. Drops whatever it's holding, falls prone. Fails STR/DEX saves. Attacks against have advantage. Any attack that hits from within 5 feet is a critical hit.

Cover.Half_Cover: +2 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws. Target has half cover if an obstacle blocks at least half of its body.
Cover.Three_Quarters_Cover: +5 bonus to AC and Dexterity saving throws. Target has three-quarters cover if about three-quarters of it is covered by an obstacle.
Cover.Full_Cover: Target can't be targeted directly by an attack or a spell, although some spells can reach such a target by including it in an area of effect.

Object_Interaction.Free_Interaction: You can interact with one object or feature of the environment for free during either your action or your move. Examples: draw or sheathe a sword, open or close a door, withdraw a potion from your backpack.
Object_Interaction.Use_an_Object_Action: If an object requires your action for its use, you take the Use an Object action. This action is also useful when you want to interact with more than one object on your turn.

Travel.Travel_Pace: Fast (4 miles/hour, -5 passive Perception), Normal (3 miles/hour), Slow (2 miles/hour, can use Stealth). Per day: Fast (30 miles), Normal (24 miles), Slow (18 miles).
Travel.Forced_March: For each additional hour of travel beyond 8 hours, characters make a DC 10 + (hours traveled beyond 8) Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of exhaustion.
Travel.Navigation: Wisdom (Survival) check to avoid getting lost. DC depends on terrain.
Travel.Foraging: Wisdom (Survival) check to find food and water. DC depends on terrain.

Vision_and_Light.Lightly_Obscured: Disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight. Examples: dim light, patchy fog, moderate foliage.
Vision_and_Light.Heavily_Obscured: Effectively blinded when trying to see something in that area. Examples: darkness, opaque fog, dense foliage.
Vision_and_Light.Darkvision: See in dim light within a specific range as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. Can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
Vision_and_Light.Truesight: See in normal and magical darkness, see invisible creatures/objects, automatically detect visual illusions, succeed on saves against them, and perceive the original form of a shapechanger or a creature transformed by magic.
